notes: Bathes in emotional, peaking waters for the first 10 minutes before Nick goes double time, settling into a rocky hot spring that overlooks a cosmic dawn, with a flock of birds migrating -> Todd's Tots.
Stays straightforward for the first half before crawling into a damp, semi-aquatic bog, where its groove echoes with deep blues and yellows, eventually sliding into sunlight and -> Salamander Song.

Drifts out to the coast and wades patiently in the sunlight before night falls, cruising past distant geometric lights that revolve and shutter in a kind of mechanical photosynthesis as they make their way toward the city. Pretty Walls-y at times.
Burrows into a dark, funky subway station, eventually bursting with energetic light.
Moves through light, Cory-led territory before swirling into outer space, orbiting patiently, then shifting into a bright, emotional gear that propels them to a close. Very Fuel-ish.
Hard-hitting Shon throughout, with an In the Eyes of Thieves feel at times.
Bubbles with static before curving down a swirling tunnel at twilight, eventually shooting through the strait to a close.

Flutters lightly before embarking on a zero-gravity walk above forested streams, skipping happily over pockets of air through the valley before reaching a gloomy, slow-motion waterfall set ablaze, dipping into -> Dirtbath.
Slightly chaotic, with an old-school Spafford sound.
Boogies harder than usual and builds nicely.

Descends into the inner workings of a city, passing underground windows of mechanized operations as robots shift through the glass and chase it to the peak. The final third wanders and wobbles a bit, but the last two minutes open up spaciously and build cleanly -> Night After Night.
Keeps watch over a harbor as ships with blaring lights stream and shuffle below, while a bridge shifts and locks into different positions, eventually opening up to a bay beneath a fiery sunset.

Flies through space with sharp synths for the first jam before landing on a Funkadelic planet in the second, where it hovers and surveils, slowly rotating into dawn as clouds timelapse through shifting hues. Patient-er than patient.
Deliciously space rodeo opera-y.
Coasts on a cool groove and has some ominous organ.
A riverboat western take on the song itself sprouts a swampy, funky jam that twinkles its way toward -> Levilan Shores.
Patiently makes its way to a nice, bright peak.
Glides through space with ease in a straightforward manner -> Peaches.
A bright take on an Anyone-esque groove that (no way!) gets trance-y and swings into a colorful jam that slides smoothly into -> Down Under.
Video game racing with a wish-washy sound throughout.
Skips from star to star inside of a disco-ball universe.
Breaks orbit and transitions smoothly -> Anyone.
Sits in a cyberpunk wind tunnel.

Moves through and alongside a projection of millions of years of activity before diving in and breaking through the atmosphere with its systems working overtime. Once it bursts through the clouds, it settles into a new, funky, bluesy, low-key groove that drifts around the horizon of a volcanic island, progressively bubbling into -> Virtual Bean Dip.
Makes its way to an Art Deco coastline at night before bursting brightly.
Robotic funk that grows with a dirty undertone.
Sort of has three parts to it: starts with standard Funkadelic, then a polished, glossy groove pops up and melts into wavy playing that swings into -> The Way You Do the Things You Do.
Straightforward, feel-good jam with incredible peaks.

song: The Way You Do the Things You Do
notes: Orbits patiently.
Boogies around the world and has a killer first buildup.
Surveils intergalactic glacial volcanoes.
Hits double-time space with a false buildup, then drops into a heavy groove and an intense peak.

Rolls through Acadian countryside and sets up camp at twilight, with beams of light falling from above, eventually lighting up the landscape. From there, the second jam swirls into a spacey, speedy, New Wave bopping groove that gets gooier as it slows and snappier as it quickens into -> Darkness Singularity.
Relaxed, cool groove with slippery synths that morphs into a cyclical trance before building into -> Stuck in the Middle with You.
Acts as a shooting star, blazing across space with color before slowing into orbit with a happy, bluesy groove that stutters and sharpens into -> Fake the Fate.
Groove-oriented, but largely same-y throughout. Great Shon with a fiery ending, though.
Grooves slickly at Shon's insistence, like Luther Vandross and Huey Lewis in molasses, before building intently for a nasty ending.
Awesome, spacey synths and an emotional ending.

song: Stuck in the Middle with You
notes: Spins through universes upon universes -> Dis Go In 5?
Robotic whisperings during a rainbow, full-body scan aboard a spaceship bursts into a dance tutorial.
Consonant, entrancing groove with heated peaks that cool into a lush stream -> Palisades.
Cools into a remote, semi-frozen northern lake at the turn from Winter to Spring, where they tinker with mechanics and happily skip across the water.
Resident spaceship band detours through the American Midwest, slips into deep space, and rockets toward -> Alternate Ending.
Direct, mechanical groove that slips into serene space just above the clouds, peaking brightly before fluttering away.
Moves through a cosmic nature preserve before emerging into an aquatic sunrise.
A loose take on Echoes goes 90s R&B mode and slips into deep, groovy space before sliding out of view.
Grooves steadily and robotically before peaking nicely and dipping into very deep space for the last few minutes.
Peaks early, then calms into a funky rhythm that gradually builds.

A look into an Artic landscape, beginning with a lone deer foraging, then splitting into hundreds of rainbow reflections endlessly leaping through the air, eventually calming into a placid, nocturnal lake that turns funky and works its way with pace and brightness to -> All My Friends.

Jazzy and low-key for the first few minutes before setting sail between icebergs illuminated by aural projections, with sod roof houses and geometric figures moving in looped animations until the energy goes out. Backup generative power kicks in, gradually reloading an underglow of white light through the landscape, eventually going into overdrive and peaking brightly before hitting the main theme, then shifting into a syncopated, plinko disco that gets spacey and drifts between colossal rocks shaped and charred by millions of years of aquatic and volcanic activity.
A dreamscape of assembly line robots working on water toward an explosive finish. -> All My Friends.
Bursts with funk early before making its way through a tunnel toward a classy, future funk-infused city, eventually pulling back to watch its relaxed, glowing skyline set in twilight.
Digital bamboo-garden groove glides past the industrial gearings of a spaceship, lands on a glitzy, jazzy dance-floor of a planet, and gets chased through canyons to a close.
Some great 'hey' jamming in the first five minutes, showcasing fantastic listening and communication from everyone. Lowkey until the final third, where they build to a close.
Upbeat chicken-scratch guitar and bluesy piano, very Dr. John at times. Turns ominous in the final minutes before going -> Walls.

The Postman goes forest mode, swims through a '90s pool commercial, and marches toward a twinkling twilight inlet, overlooking contemplatively before plunging in and skipping into -> Electric Taco Stand.
Spirograph funk blooms into excellent, emotional peaks before easing into reflective, pastoral space -> Diana.
Electro groove takes a scenic trip through intergalactic valleys and mountains, building to a radiant peak before settling into a calm awakening in a bubbling hot spring.
Immersive atmosphere with a groove that builds cleanly.
Hypnotic groove.

Eccentric, upbeat funk sprouts in the final 10 minutes, with wailing guitar surfing above. Lands somewhere between Galisteo Way, All My Friends, and Broken Wing, before an energetic build and smooth slide -> Back in L.A.
Lowkey, spacious ETS-style groove that builds serenely.
Customary funk melts into glowing cave paintings of molten lava.
An initial celebratory drill launches into mechanically circular space, building brightly before swirling into melancholic yet uplifting bluesy territory.
Toys with an Echoes-adjacent groove in the first half before splashing through a Salamander Song stream in the second. -> Salamander Song.
A solid spin on the usual synthpop for the first two thirds, before slipping into an unexpected, slinky groove with Cory teasing Echoes that speeds its way back into -> Duncan's Uncle.
Bounces on water and stays lowkey, with a smooth slide -> Anyone.
A transitive walk through gooey sprinkler showers as dawn breaks across slightly manicured fields, with sprawling guitar and a fierce sunrise.
Nimble to start, patient through the second and final thirds, and emotive throughout.
A glossy, saturated, bouncy groove emerges, riding along until it ramps up cleanly to a close.
Determined playing throughout, with a circular groove and tastes of different spaces thanks to Cory's keys.
Waterfalls and forests glow under sizzling lamps, growing hotter until they burst into radiant flames.
Standard until the last five minutes, where they slowly build their way -> Swingtown.
Upbeat, consistent, and groovy until 13:50, when they drop into a fantastic rave that works its way to a rocket launch transition -> Ain't That Wrong.
Straightforward, but Shon lays down an awesome, steady groove.
Moves through a shimmering, timbered wilderness before dipping its toes into the water, swimming downstream, and eventually fading into night -> High Beams. Absolutely beautiful scenery.
The first opener since 6/11/23 (Press Room, Portsmouth, NH) ending a 190 show gap.

song: The Way You Do the Things You Do
notes: Trudges through gooey (sorta lethargic) space before moving onto a dazzling dancefloor. A round of peaks, and then a choppy groove that builds brightly -> Back in L.A.
A bit out of the box, with some slowdowns, and samples.
Dub-y and Funkadelic-y to start, slowing at a space terminal before swirling into a dancey strait with a fiery finish.
Straightforward first half that flies by, then Funkadelic-ish jamming that experiments with several combinations before opening up into an 8-bit groove that eventually swings -> Walls.
Mostly the usual structure, but much spacier.
Hustles in double time before hitting a section straight from Windmill, then quickly moves through a corridor of buzzing lights and into a dense, foggy jungle -> Broken Wing.
A revolving carousel of a groove that builds sharply and reflects brightly.
Rushes into a funky, mechanical marshland, where it churns until the peak.

The roof opens to an Arctic forest doused in constellations that steadily scorches its way back to the main theme. From there, it becomes a mid-morning drive through the countryside, rolling onto  and around a nocturnal, deeply colorful electric dancefloor by highway studded with floating crystals. It grows ominous, features a phone-call sample, and goes -> Can't Catch Me Now.
Transparent blocks and containers of light drop and neatly sort themselves above the countryside.
Awesome keys, samples, and time changes in the first few minutes. A bit of icing on the cake for Chuck's birthday.
Brighter than usual, with a robotic entity happily sending out signals and painting the universe with its blazing trail.
Spends its final minutes building serenely -> Anyone.

Strobes scatteredly before touring the inner workings of an open-air ship, surfacing to a Monaco coastline dazzling with nightlife and riddled with traffic, then builds brightly into a radiant sunrise.
Swirls into outer space, swims for a bit, and then explodes into a star.
Stomps its way into a disco at Shon's insistence, slowly building before a quick implosion -> Space Gadget.
A swampy, funky groove emerges and sticks until spacey, windchime-y keys appear, swooning to the edge of the atmosphere, where things slowly get angry and go -> Dis Go In 5?
Briefly calms down into a peaceful garden inside of a spaceship before building -> Who Can It Be Now?
Shiny, regenerative groove that catches storm warnings and takes shelter in a funky basement.

Keeps the swampy theme alive with Shon's colorful green and brown tones, then swirls underwater to swim through a parallel outer space, revolving around a sun before and during an eclipse, rotating steadily -> Ain't That Wrong.
Calms down into a soulful, minimalistic scene that drifts -> Palisades.
Pokes and prods in the dark before briefly stumbling on a celestial celebration, then slips into customary electro-rock and drifts into serene, tribal-tinged waters that go -> The Other One.
Straightforward, but bright throughout and done well.

A soundstage of an early 1980s Caribbean dancehall that pulses circuitously through the night until a distant early warning is heard and it responds with sharper pace and direction. Absolutely fantastic work and determination from everyone, especially Brian.
Snappier than usual and outside the box, with some nice space.
Floats into outer space and attaches to a repetitive, entrancing groove for a good while until Cory steps up with organ and they start to work towards a peak.

Triggered consecutive implosions to carve artificial canyons on the crest of the city, letting shades of light surface. A nighttime flyover leads to a clash between auroras and city lights, building to a monstrous peak that settles down, slyly boogies, and incredibly rocks its way -> Night After Night.
Grooves dreamily for its first half before being searched for by an intergalactic yeti and its planetary spotlight, eventually reaching a gloomy waterside that brightens to a close.
Slinks its way around a pond garden with a heavy presence. Great stuff from Brian throughout.

Some unusual rave-y vocal samples pop up after a few minutes, swirling out of thick clouds and hovering over a duplitecture of a city, sensing glowing architectural patterns mapped out by Shon's bass and streets of glossy, running streams that Cory paves. It speeds up quickly and closes out perfectly. Look out!
Bobs steadily with a low-key groove for a good bit.
Straightforward, but peaks nicely and has some bluesy playing at the end that drops into Cantaloupe Island.
Super smooth, with a soulful solo from Brian.

A rainbow's take on the "second story basement in an underwater matrix" to start, with vibrant colors from everyone and a speedy pace on display. It cools down in the final third, coasting somewhere between Careful With That Axe, Eugene and Breakdown (Petty), before building -> Motel 6.
Drifts out to sea and onto a cloud where it bathes in misty, monochromatic green air.
Bounces for a bit before sliding into a familiar intergalactic rave that builds angrily -> Virtual Bean Dip.
Extra synth goodness with poised playing throughout.
Basically Night After Night for the first half, then swims downstream into patient, soulful playing and slides off a waterfall -> Windmill.
Upbeat funk that that slowly turns straight boogie, moves through emotional early-2000s and lands softly.
Sharp synthpop slides into a chill, arid garden and climbs to a peak.
Quickly latches onto a syncopated groove and makes its way to feel-good, Summer-time territory.
Upbeat and locked in from the start, then meanders through vocal sample territory before finding its footing on a rumbling, determined groove.
Serene, free-flowing jamming in the first half that swings into clean peaks. Some Funkadelic-ish grooving in the last 10 minutes that slides outside to a nature preserve and -> The Postman.
Stutter-step funk with a repetitive grand piano that builds brightly. Killer Brian in the final third.
Funky, flower-garden groove melts in place with loops swirling overhead before warming up and dancing down the Soul Train Line.
First appearance since 12/31/19 (San Francisco, CA), ending a 408 show gap. Lots of samples from Cory.
An earworm of a groove that pedals mechanically, with a soaring, atmospheric background that teases its way to a beautiful buildup. Like the sun peeking out from clouds.
Summertime groove turns electronically somber. -> Aliens.
Mechanical showering in a rainbow-glowing jungle at night.
Slinks its way to a beautiful buildup and lands on a double time groove for the last few minutes.
Upbeat and funky, moving through 1980s streets before building anxiously. Gets quiet for a minute, then grooves cleanly into -> Anyone.
More intense than usual to start and determined throughout.
Standard groove turns dancey before Cory slides and hammers on the grand piano. Ramps up and drops cleanly -> Can't Find My Vape.

Wobbly funk swirls into a shimmering swamp of spacey synths and poppy beats, then Brian takes over for an early-2000s groove that swells and drops into brief space before a celestial, celebratory close.
A streaky, funky groove gets concentrated and almost robotic. Cool stuff from Cory and Shon throughout.
The first jammed version. Toys with a playful groove.
Plucky, windchime-y keys from Cory over a sprinkler-patterned, ska-tinted groove, with a powerful final third.
Patient funk that churns slowly for a while and works its way to -> The Postman.
Dub-y for a bit and builds intently.

Funky with a distinct Echoes-like sound for the first few minutes that shifts to super groovy, Shon-driven space where they sway as a unit before hitting the peak. Some colorful playing that in the last minute or so that fades > Dissociation Assist.
Swirls into a heavy, trancey groove that builds sharply before a rocking close.
Slinky, slow groove with some awesome Shon that grows angry.
Starts out with some surprising jump blues and gets weirder before hitting an early peak that Brian crushes. Some extra, hoppy, Funkadelic-ish jamming in the back third.
Hang gliding over indoor oceans and starlit shores. -> Walls.
Standard, but done well. Nice buildup -> Broken Wing.
Bouncy, groovy, and picks up speed half way through for a 1970s progressive rock buildup and peak.
Instantly latches to a P-Funk groove that Shon gets turned way up for. One of the best buildups ever here.
Early Electro House, with some crazy stuff from Brian towards the end.
Heated playing from Brian on display.

A cyclical disco by nature, one that progresses patiently and consistently. Its groove morphs subtly and funkily, building to a soaring peak that Brian explodes over, and finishes with a twilight-tinted slide -> War of Man.
Steadily up-tempo and sticking with a danceable groove that just won't quit, this one anxiously works its way up a cliff that abruptly drops off into -> Alternate Ending.

Drifts into a simulated rice field under a projection of a blue sky, as gigantic intergalactic beasts of vehicles stroll into the scene, tearing the fabric of the projected sky and leaving behind a wide, shining rainbow that speeds up time before straightening out for a celebratory build back into ETS.

Glides and rewinds in stuttering motion down a mountainside blanketed with snow, gaining speed as it robotically dodges rocks, branches, and terrain as if it were on rails before slipping into a deep hibernation dimly lit by swirling colors and muted hues. From there, it takes its time to wake up with neat, bluesy playing that turns bright and reels into several minutes of ETS teasing that, you guessed it, goes -> ETS.

Cory slides in with some synths around the 7:00 mark, hits the echo 45 seconds later, then wipes them into atmospheric, funky, rumbling space that he and Shon control for most of the jam. Last few minutes has a powerful Brian on display. More than a few "this is the first set!?" moments here.
Rotates funkily for its first half, hits a clean buildup, then waltzes through slick, jazzy territory that bobs steadily and implodes to the ending.
Upbeat and fun, shifting through busy lanes with poise and a determined pace before shooting out of the city and then the atmosphere.
An Ibizan rainforest speckled with spry, swirling stars that industrializes toward a customary peaking section.

Quickly drops into a smoke-filled underwater Matrix in a second story basement and breaks out to fiercely bright skies before finding its way to a slinking, Echoes-y groove that fades and goes -> Double Time.
Has an easygoing, Summer-time groove. The shortest version of the year (?)
Locks in on a consonant groove that Cory works his magic over for the first half before Brian unleashes for the second half. Some really good Shon here.
Starts out with an Anyone-esque groove, brightens, finds itself on a gothic dancefloor of sorts, and goes -> Walls.
A late-night, mid-century modern drive with a nice groove to it that swells with electric nervousness and descends into smoother space to > In the Eyes of Thieves. Fantastic.
Bookending a Walls -> Made for Wesley -> Walls sandwich, this one utilizes a familiar groove and features a scorching last few minutes where Brian steals the show.
Quickly drops into a cosmic aquarium tunnel that reaches surprising depth and gets trippy. -> Made for Wesley.
Some Spring-time sounds from Cory throughout and a nice groove that quickens and brightens to the end.
Drifts along a Longview-like beachside and into spacious, warm water that rolls to a peak. Great stuff from Brian towards the end.
Instantly hits a funky groove, quickly gives way to a vocal jam, and returns for some awesome P-Funk that moves through a mechanical checkpoint and drifts slightly out of orbit.
A feel-good vibe that bobbles steadily for a good bit, then floats along shimmering, saturated, heavy water -> Night After Night.
Lush in parts and progresses nicely.
Supremely funky and up-tempo, this one swirls into an Anatolian suite and breaks out with power.

Funky through the first half and propels into a spacey rave with a very strong Shon and steady Nick. Brian takes over in the last few minutes for some great emotive playing. The start of a ETS > Dis Go In 5? > ETS sandwich.
Starts out with a mechanical groove, gains traction and soars with a contemplative Cory behind it, then glides through sunset lava lamp constellations -> Electric Taco Stand.
Extended electro house with a few big buildups.
Features Tim Palmieri on guitar and starts with some synthpop, turns electronic, and swirls into sharper cat-and-mouse between Brian and Tim. Clean slide into the ending.
Settles on anticipated funk before building to an early 2000s Electro close.
Unreal Tournament 1999 x Rainbow Road x Star Wars Episode I Racer. (Colorful drum and bass turns jazzy, shifts to funkier space, and exits with power -> Neutrino.)
An entrancing Latin jazz rave that slides into a concentrated groove that Cory dances over with several keyboards before settling on the grand piano.
Lethargic through much of the first half, but swirls into a Miami nightclub around 9:00, peaks soulfully with a twinkling comedown, and has a feel-good roots rock build -> Mind's Unchained.
Short, but doesn't feel like it. A tiny bit atmospheric to start the jam and a strong, blues-y Southern Rock second half.
Mostly standard, but goes double time for a minute or so towards the end.
Awesome groove with standout Shon that gets a bit evil at times. Awkward first step into Broken Wing, but smooths out for the transition.
Starts out slow and funky, with some sample manipulation from Cory before going breakbeat. Gets spacey in the middle.
Stutter-step funk with a brief electro phase.

PlayStation 1 nostalgia ambient atmospheric jungle drum and bass mix.



(Truly inspired, up-tempo drum and bass. Easily one of the best versions this year.)
A whirring, Afro-Funk solo from Cory and tight throughout.
Feat. Rob Compa on guitar. Starts out with a metronomic groove before turning spacey and dancey. Some cool sheets of sonic rain from Cory launch them into a rocket-race between Brian and Rob.
A slick, saturated groove sprouts with the help of ever-consistent Shon, loops hanging overhead before building with bite. Some delicate, serene playing stumbles into another lowkey groove to close.
Funky with some sharp synths and a screeching close.
An open-air train ride through mountains just before dawn, with a sprawling sunrise.
Awesome, engaging, up-beat Electro-Disco that slips out of orbit, climbs into a sunspot, and bursts with color. Ferocious.

One of those "this one's going to be different" moments as they slide into the jam. Starting with a funkier base than usual, it moves through polished synthpop, a brief but stunning atmospheric passage, more funk, and has some great guitar work from Brian at the end.
Ice skating on a haptic rainbow Alp during a solar eclipse.
Ethereal atmosphere blooms into a steady groove that peaks around 20:00, then goes back into atmospheric space before turning celebratory to close.
Relaxed groove that turns spacey and boards a midnight sky train with shimmering lights and shapes below. Big sunrise build > Todd's Tots.

A determined groove pops up instantly, diving into an underwater matrix in a second story basement that opens into a rave. Huge buildup around 12:00, followed by fluttery, feel good playing that bursts with pride > Salamander Song.
Just the fifth ever show opener and a good one at that, steadily marching its way into playful groove that Cory lays synths on top of. Nice build and fade -> Fake the Fate.
A signature Spafford groove develops and wipes into repetitive, patient space for several minutes. Snare hit at 12:35 and they're off to another mini-buildup and drop.

Locks onto an entrancing groove that gets down early and delivers an awesome first 15 minutes. A few meandering moments thereafter, but they swing colorfully into another hard-hitting groove and hit peaks before closing out. Great.
Ethereal with ambient swells for a good few minutes before some midi/mutron playing from Brian that flows neatly to peaks.
Around 12:00, beams of synths begin to soar through a pristine summer Arctic landscape before  driving into a nocturnal Northern European city with a steady groove -> In the Eyes of Thieves.
Smoothly slides from a rainy, tropical purple backyard into a churning late-night intergalactic disco, with some face-melting shredding from Brian and nice playing from Cory before closing out.
Just the fifth show opener to date, this one gets excited early and spends its first 17 minutes brightly building to an explosive peak. Final third features some blues-y playing -> Ice Cream.
Ska turns into an airy, nighttime groove -> Down Under.

Races through an intergalactic jungle war zone on an up-tempo, cyclical groove that weaves around monorails and hovering structures, with an electrical grid glowing beneath in volcanic yellows and oranges. Killer throughout, with a very clean slide to close.
Debut. Colorfully funky and deliciously electronic.
Fluttery and intricate first half.
Meditative groove that's easy to get lost in.
Extra juice, with some hard-hitting, emotional guitar work.
A groove straight from Off the Wall (Michael Jackson) that soars through space and peaks nicely.
A tale of two halves: first, Frogger in a dense, metallic-green jungle where nothing feels real; then, a steady groove sprouts from the main theme and builds with pace and energy -> Motel 6.
Consistent rave that flutters into Palisades.
Celebratory, with an incredible Brian.

A Duncan's Uncle-esque groove that drifts through vocal pad trance, hits a sharp peak, and circles back with a low-key take on the earlier groove before building (impressively!) to -> Night After Night.
Settles on a relaxed, thumping groove driven by Shon and has a chaotic, slightly jazzy buildup.
Goes double time and moves into colorful, iridescent electro before peaking with power.

Goes through deep funk before sliding into an awesome, glacial landscape that runs through a couple of powerful yet somber peaks before filtering out. Some killer Brian here, and a great, loud full-band sound.
Bounces on pristine, colorful tiles soaked in sunlight, exerting immense energy in what seems an impossible attempt to reach the top, and gets rewarded with the view of a lifetime.

Breaks out from the quiet part (the quiet part!) into spectacular, electronically dyed, entrancing space that grows eclectically and powers its way back into the second half of the song proper. Everything you've ever wanted.
Spacey, loopy, and showcases several different time signatures and new electronics.
The usual deal (but done very well) for the first half, then gets funky and works its way toward a peak straight out of Salamander Song, before slamming into Salamander Song itself.

An open-air amphitheater tucked in patches of thick, lush grass within a city, framed by buildings looming overhead as stutter-step funk echoes through the park until the sun sets, when things get atmospheric and peak with the moon's rise.
Sunbathes in a springtime mountainous stream.

Swirls into deep space, finding it self in a jazzy strait of miniature planets before descending to an angular alleyway, guided by flares pointing to a massive, nondescript facility buried deep within an industrialized city. Inside lies a limestone cave studded with stalactites and subwoofers, housing a mechanical rave and opening onto an enormous quartz block where purple lights strobe and shadows skip against perfectly placed pillars until the scene zooms out to a galactic tea garden.
Bounces into vast outer space for the first half and travels through an unexpectedly happy cycle in the second, with a bright, satisfying peak and a calm end.

Instantly gets incredibly airy and spacious, like swaths of grass swaying in the wind chiming softly, before growing electronic and drifting into an outer-space lullaby that rocks and revolves around a glitzy disco ball.
Bobs into an entrancing rave.
Powerful!

Gets neuralyzed and transported into the doorway of an intergalactic hallway, one end opening onto a busy railway of imperfectly rendered trains, each looping and weaving in random animations. Sound bounces from a second story basement nearby as a heat signature alert leads to a chase and big peak -> Alternate Ending.
A noticeably strong start that makes its way into a geodesic sphere containing millions of galaxies, radiating in transcendent shapes and forms of different colors and intensities.
Spacey to start and incredibly tight throughout.
Washes into rich, shimmering space where it floats tranquilly before shooting back through the atmosphere to reach the main theme. Fantastic.
Incredibly strong, with tight playing from everyone, a celebratory jam, and a beautiful, hard-hitting final couple of minutes.
Coming round from an exceptional Anyone, this one sways patiently for a couple of minutes before going straight into its ending. OHHHHHHHHHHH!
An easy-to-digest groove that blooms around the 15-minute mark before descending into an abandoned lakeside amphitheater.
Cool throughout, with an extra buildup, too. Really slick.

An ear-ringing call from outer space leads to a trip in a hopping space rover, bright light dyeing its metallic body in assorted washed-out colors as its climbs through rocky terrain, hits a major peak with a triple moonrise, then calms down and builds -> Night After Night.

Ziplines into a world filled with translucent pink and purple blobs of jelly breathing as random units, then builds into a travelator within an infinite pattern of gold and steel pyramids that snap and unfold into and onto each other. The second jam features a funky groove that grows spacious and joyful.
Surfaces to an underwater strip of rainbow belts, where it cruises and bounces signals back and forth until it peaks sharply and calms considerably.
An exceptional run through with a repetitive groove that spins electrically, grows mechanically, and explodes with incredible force.

Looks for ghosts in and along industrial piping before driving down a dusty highway at sunset, the frame of the vehicle melting away until night falls, when a thick fog surrounds them and transports them into deep space, where they drift for a bit before gearing back up with a funky groove that eventually winds down.

Woodpecking into liquid glass shatters the universe into goo, building to a monstrous peak that Brian slays. From there, it relaxes into a northern seaside park, misty breeze running through, where angelic visions briefly appear before giving way to a tribal buildup -> Dirtbath.
This one's a rager!

song: Shu Ba Da Du Ma Ma Ma Ma
notes: Micro jam packed with peaks.
Very colorful electro that widens into space and goes -> Legend of Zelda.

A quick Hood jam (in reference to the previous night's "I said when we 'knew' how to play that, not 'know'" banter) that slow-drips across a simulated Moab desert, surveils for extraterrestrial life, then explodes into the sun and dissipates.
Standard funk quiets, then builds into atmospheric, mechanical disco dream pop that peaks fantastically and has a cool outro -> Soggy Froggy.
A much happier take on the usual deal.
Shakes into a late night drive lit by striving lights and echoing sounds.
Slick grooving morphs into vibrant electro that grows hot and hits hard.
Dreams into a dark box with a window looking out to a small coastline and an endless ocean, while the sunrise gradually fills the room with refracted colors.
Devastatingly good final minute or so.
Afro-funk space invasion.

Jam starts at the midway point of the song and sprouts like a universe from a lone, halfway-planted seed, adorned with silk waterfalls that bend and mist minimalistic drumming as they rotate through space, setting course for an exploding star where they peak spectacularly.

White hot playing from Brian between verses and a light, bouncy start to the jam that grows groovy as it dips its toes in a stream, electrifying the surrounding area to the maximum. Then they skip into deep space, working their way into a guarded, semi-industrialized village that raves away.

"Shon... funkdalelic? Spun... kadelic? Ska punk-adelic. OH, it's sped up!" 



Colorful, mechanical space disco that races from start to finish.

song: The Way You Do the Things You Do
notes: Wharf Rat-y and Dark Star-ish, peaking fiercely before snapping into a power-building groove that grows chaotic.

Moves into a strobing, vibrant disco framed by comforting, blinking, and twirling lights that grows radiant and triumphant until it peaks with the main theme. The second jam begins with a hard-hitting, Funkadelic-style groove before giving way to a soundscape of glacial streams flowing through rock formations that lead to an alien ceremony, followed by streaky guitar and a buildup straight out of Darkness Singularity.
Two jams, both of which show off a lot of new sounds but ultimately make for straightforward jamtronica.

A looser start to the jam than usual, with playful Off the Wall / Wanna Be Startin’ Somethin’ teasing before stepping into a shower of vibrating meteors whose particles dash and shift positions with sharp color, making for a big buildup and a spacey exit.
Piercing, soulful guitar playing throughout.
Aliens-esque, noisy deep space.
Cool, colorful grooving, but a bit same-y in spots.
Dissipates into a hazy, misty coastal highway before gearing into a Double Time-y buildup.
Sails into a spacey, joyful, and repetitive groove before marching away.
Really well done Type I jam.

Lowered into an Arctic race at the peak of a solar eclipse, this one moves blindly through an infinite landscape, waving at holograms of competitors from decades past until the sun strikes just right and shatters their vision into greyscale, with flashes of orange in their peripheral vision that burst into raging flames, and has a somber revisit years later.
Swanky, funky grooving that gradually speeds up as it gets spacier, dazzling its way toward -> Can't Find My Vape with an awesome transition.
One of Brian's guitar strings uncoils, prompting some fun improv from the other three before he returns to demolish with an explosive finish.
Lots of different keys from Cory, with a cool yacht rock jam that builds cleanly.
Back and forth alien chatter.
